div.head: YOU NEVER KNOW YOUR LUCK.
div.p: A bylaw of the New York Board of Education says:

"No married woman shall be appointed to any teaching or supervising position in the New York public schools unless her husband is mentally or physically incapacitated to earn a living, or has deserted her for a period of not less than one year. Satisfactory proof of such incapacity or desertion must be presented to the Board of Education."

lg.l: All other pleas appear to us

sp.speaker: 1st Teacher
sp.l: My husband is not really bad—

sp.speaker: Board
sp.l: How very sad, how very sad!

sp.speaker: 1st Teacher
sp.l: He's good, but hear my one excuse—

sp.speaker: Board
sp.l: Oh, what's the use; oh, what's the use?

sp.speaker: 1st Teacher
sp.l: Last winter in a railroad wreck
He lost an arm and broke his neck.
He's doomed, but lingers day by day.

sp.speaker: Board
sp.l: Her husband's doomed! Hurray, hurray!

sp.speaker: 2nd Teacher
sp.l: My husband's kind, and healthy, too.

sp.speaker: Board
sp.l: Why, then, of course, you will not do.

sp.speaker: 2nd Teacher
sp.l: Just hear me out. You'll find you're wrong.
It's true his body's good and strong:
But, ah, his wits are all astray.

sp.speaker: Board
sp.l: Her husband's mad! Hip, hip, hurray!

sp.speaker: 3rd Teacher
sp.l: My husband's wise and well—the creature!

sp.speaker: Board
sp.l: Then you can never be a teacher.

sp.speaker: 3rd Teacher
sp.l: Wait. For I led him such a life,
He could not stand me as a wife;
Last Michaelmas he ran away.

sp.speaker: Board
sp.l: Her husband hates her. Hip, hurray!

lg.l: No teacher need apply to us

div.head: ASK YOUR FATHER.
div.p: The New York Board of Education gives as the first cause for which leave of absence may be granted: Serious personal illness of the teacher.
We have not yet discovered whether the illness incident to bearing a child is not serious, or not personal.

div.head: OUR OWN ANTI-SUFFRAGE COLUMN.
div.p: (Drawn from letters to "The New York Times" of February 14, 1915.)

div.head: TOO CLOSELY, SOME THINK.
div.p: Party politics deal with the business aspects of government. It is man's business, and is closely related to his personal business.—Mrs. Arthur M. Dodge.

div.head: NOTHING TO WIVES AND MOTHERS.
div.p: With battles to be fought by men, and men's lives to be sacrificed, it would seem only fair that men alone should determine a nation's policy.—J. Howard Cowperthwaite.

div.head: SOME OLD-FASHIONED COMPLIMENTS.
div.p: Rebellious women think they can grow to do all things as well as men. . . . They excel in two things—nursing and singing soprano.—E. G. K.
Men are practical and just, and women are temperamentally impressionable, erratic and very theoretical.—W. F. Quinn, Alderman, 15th District.
A few descriptive terms selected at random: Restless, dissatisfied, wild, shrieking, blatant, loud-voiced, female demagogues and chronic limelight hunters.

div.head: VERY FITTING.
div.p: One grandmother in St. Louis is reported to have been influenced by "The Times" anti-suffrage editorial.

lg.l: I pity those with all my heart
Who think they play, through good and ill,
A wise, a safe, a prudent part
They think they're cautious, sure and strong,
"This rock has blocked the stream too long,
It's time to blast it all away.
